Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Trans voters can obtain a U.S. passport or passport card that reflects their gender identity without needing to provide underlying documentation.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Trans voters can obtain a U.S. passport or passport card that reflects their gender identity without needing to provide underlying documentation.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey is widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is a chilling effect,” said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis is the CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans votes count,” said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Ankit Rastogi is the director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID. And so when a state goes out of its way to enforce its message about its belief about sex and gender on a license, and transgender people then have to publicize that when they show other people, it creates a dangerous environment,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn is an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people,” said Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Rose Saxe is the deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding,” Diaz said. “And really to scare trans folks from even participating and getting the license if they needed to update it.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz is a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “They won’t stop me, but I can see how it would stop others,” she said. “It is almost certainly stopping some people from showing up at the polls.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs is a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Something that’s very frustrating for us at VoteRiders is you will never be able to capture the number of people who do not feel safe voting, and who therefore stay home. And you also won’t be able to capture the people who are trans and show up to try and vote and are turned away.” Kunis said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis is the CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are definitely the physical dangers, the dangers for harassment, discrimination — but also ultimately, voter suppression,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn is an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It really shows the resiliency of the trans community to ensure that our voices are heard and we have visibility at the ballot box,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of voting and elections for the group that conducted the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Josie Caballero is the director of voting and elections for the group that conducted the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There’s nothing these laws will do to stop me from living my best life,” she said. “It just puts my energy and passion towards making this place better for me and other trans people.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs is a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Kansas, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union have drafted a letter reminding election workers that a gender marker on a person’s identification does not need to match or correspond to a voter’s gender expression.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In eight battleground states, the nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The nonprofit VoteRiders is on the ground helping voters get the identification they need to cast ballots in the November election — and one that reflects who they are.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Equality Florida, the state’s leading LGBTQ+ advocacy group, is holding “know your rights” trainings in the wake of new regulations barring many transgender voters from obtaining photo identification that reflects their gender.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: At least nine states in the past two years have explicitly regulated gender in this way, according to a tally by the Movement Advancement Project (MAP), which tracks LGBTQ+ policy.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Movement Advancement Project (MAP) tracks LGBTQ+ policy.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders, found that nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The ACLU, which is tracking some of these laws and rules, has tried to prepare election workers on how to process trans voters who come into their polling sites.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The ACLU is tracking some of these laws and rules and has tried to prepare election workers on how to process trans voters who come into their polling sites.
